title: Scammer jailed for ‘bleeding lonely hearts dry’
text:
Lonely hearts fraudster jailed over 11 counts of scamming money from older men SARAH CRAWFORD, The Daily Telegraph February 23, 2017 5:17pm 
A WELFARE mum of four who took more than $2.7 million from lonely old men looking for love was jailed for 18 months, with the sentencing judge saying the 41-year-old had set out to “bleed them dry”. 
Sanaa Derbas, who has had large amounts of plastic surgery, used dating websites to con six men out of millions by claiming her mother or even one of her children had died. 
One victim told her he was left with just $20 in his bank account, while another said he could not pay his children’s school fees. media_camera Derbas would invite prospective dates to meet her at a motel and ask for payment for the room before cancelling, saying her mother had died. 
Judge Paul Conlon slammed Derbas when he sentenced her today for 11 counts of dishonestly obtaining money by deception, saying she had shown “unwavering determination to dishonestly deceive each victim” targeting “lonely, vulnerable people” who were craving companionship. 
Derbas defrauded her victims, aged between 69 and 43, between September 2008 until she was arrested on March 2014. 
Court documents reveal Derbas would meet her victims through dating services including the phone service Lavalife and Clique Introductions, whose website states it provides for “casual affairs”. media_camera Derbas said she spent her takings on cocaine and gambling. Picture: Facebook media_camera No money taken was spent on plastic surgery, she said. Picture: Facebook 
She would invite the men to meet her at a hotel and then ask them to transfer up to $600 into her account so she could book the room. 
Then she would cancel the date, giving excuses including that her mother had been taken to hospital and had died. 
She would then ask for money to help pay for the funeral costs or her mortgage repayments, saying her rich grandfather in Egypt would pay them back. 
Derbas would then continue to ask for money, saying she needed to pay transfer fees or taxes before her grandfather’s money would be released. 
When police raided her Miller home in Western Sydney, they found three diaries containing 349 mens’ names along with her female aliases including “Sarina Lopez”, “Sarrina” and “Marrisa “. 
Police also found 15 phones with one containing her text exchanges with 20 other men who were not among victims. 
Derbas told the court she blew the money on cocaine and gambling addictions among other things. 
The court heard she had multiple plastic surgeries including three liposuctions, Botox, lip fillers, eye fillers and nasal reconstruction, but did not say she spent the ill-gotten money on transforming her body. IN OTHER NEWS: WHO IS AHMED FAHOUR? Ahmed Fahour quits as Australia Post CEO 1:48 
Australia Post CEO Ahmed Fahour has resigned from his position and will leave in July. February 23rd 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/News/ Ahmed Fahour quits as Australia Post CEO 
Judge Conlon said Derbas was motivated by greed and in her own words viewed the frauds as her “new business”. 
The Crown told the court that since she had pleaded guilty in August last year she had been compelled to sell her home in Miller and use all the money in her 16 bank accounts to pay back her victims. So far she has paid them a total of $745,000. 
“It was agreed that this will equate to the victims receiving a return of about 32 cents in the dollar,” Judge Conlon said. 
Derbas was sentenced to three years and six months with 18 months non-parole. She will be released on August 22, 2018.
